Dialogue: Not if I can help it.

Dialogue: Please don't cry... I can't stand to see somebody cry.

Dialogue: What are you doing?

Dialogue: I don't know, Sergeant. To be honest, I don't know.

Dialogue: Maybe... why not?

Dialogue: How about Payday?

Dialogue: You don't have to spend money on me, Sergeant.

Dialogue: Maybe.

Dialogue: Come on, you dirty sons --

Speaker: another angle
Dialogue: as Warden comes up on the roof through the skylight. He shouts incoherently at the men. They shout back in a wild cheer. They are like a pack of hungry men enjoying their first big meal in years. In b.g. the Jap V has swung about and heads back. Warden grabs a BAR from the roof.

Speaker: another angle
Dialogue: Warden makes a tour of the roof, laughing, exhorting, slapping the men on their buttocks like a quarterback. They respond with tremendous spirit; they are having one hell of a time. We get only a snatch of what Warden is yelling.

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: -- Don't worry about wasting ammo! Throw your empty clips down into the yard. The loading detail will pick 'em up --

Speaker: treadwell
Dialogue: Friday's gone crazy! He's blowing the Cavalry Charge!

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: Oh, those dirty Germans... Those dirty sneakin Germans...

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: What Germans?!

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: Them...

Speaker: gorgette
Dialogue: It's the Japs. The Japs!

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: ... dirty Germans...

Speaker: full shot
Dialogue: The Jap strafing attack is continuing. Their planes are making a figure 8 in the sky. Silhouettes of men on the roof can b e seen. Friday Clark is blowing his Cavalry Charge. In b.g. men of the loading detail are scurrying around. Lieutenant Ross runs into shot. CAMERA PANS him across the quadrangle toward the barracks.

Speaker: full shot
Dialogue: As before, pandemonium -- but controlled and efficient. The men are hoarse from shouting, red-eyed, puffing from excitement and exertion. Two Jap planes swoop past and the full-throated umbrella of fire lets loose. Lieutenant Ross clambers onto the roof, stooping under the burden of the BAR and loading clips. The men greet him with a concerted cheer.

Speaker: dhom's voice
Dialogue: HERE THEY COME, MEN!

Speaker: karelsen
Dialogue: Nuts! Led him too tar.

Speaker: medium shot
Dialogue: as the men on the roof reload. In the distance the Jap planes have turned and are heading back for the roof.

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: You got him, Pete! You got him!

Speaker: karelsen
Dialogue: Ah, nobody'll ever know which of us got that guy.

Speaker: another angle
Dialogue: as the men return to their positions. Two planes head for them, pass over as Company G lets go again with everything it has.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Hey! That last one was one of ours! That was an American plane!

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: Well, he ain't got no business here. We're takin care of this sector!

Speaker: ross
Dialogue: HERE COMES A JAP!

Speaker: medium shot
Dialogue: The men flatten, all but Warden. He stands, swings his BAR toward the plane. CAMERA IS ANGLED so that Warden is silhouetted against the sky as he fires at the Jap plane.

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: Alma! Alma!

Speaker: prew's voice
Dialogue: Alma!

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: They're pickin trouble with the best Army in -- the best riflemen -- you know we the ony country on the face of the earth that uses the shooting gunsling, not the carrying gunsling. You know that?

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: We've been at Queens Hospital -- giving blood --

Speaker: gorgette
Dialogue: The town's a madhouse. Trucks, busses, jeeps all over --

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: A house on Kuhio Street was bombed OUT --

Speaker: gorgette
Dialogue: And the drugstore on McKully and King is smashed flat. And the man and his wife were killed --

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: I gotta get back to the Post -- I'll try to get in touch with you in a couple days --

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: The Post? Tonight?

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: But why?

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: Why? There's a war goin on.

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: But you can't! You're not fit yet -- you're weak as a kitten -- you're AWOL -- they'll throw you in the STOCKADE --

Speaker: prep
Dialogue: They'll be throwin `em out of the Stockade. They need every man they can get.

Speaker: gorgette
Dialogue: Your side'll open up --

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: And they'll find out it was you who killed that soldier!

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: Once I report in to the Compny I'll be all right. Once I get there. I gotta get back --

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: But you'll never make it! There's MPs all over --

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: I'll make it. I'll go along the back roads. They'll let me in the West gate -- they'll know I'm a SOLJER --

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: Stay till morning!

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: Maybe if you stayed till morning you'd change your mind...

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: Don't go, Prew! I'll do whatever you want... We'll figure out a way to get to the States together... We can even get married... If you go I won't see you any more... I know it...

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: What do you want to go back to the Army for?! What did the Army ever do for you? Besides treat you like scum and give you one awful going over and get your friend killed? What do you want to go back to that for?

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: What do I want to go back for? I'm a soljer.

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: A soldier! A soldier! A Regular. From the Regular Army. A thirty- year man!

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: Sure. A thirty-year man.  With only twenty-six years to go.

Speaker: first mp
Dialogue: They say they seen parachutists land up in the mountains.

Speaker: second mp
Dialogue: I ain't worried about them. Sabatoors is what worries me.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Yeah. Theys the creepy ones. Walkin around just like ordinary civilians. I betcha they operatin all over these islands.

Speaker: mp's voice
Dialogue: Halt!

Speaker: medium shot
Dialogue: Prew rises, staggers away from the jeep.

Speaker: mp's voice
Dialogue: HALT!

Speaker: prew
Dialogue: -- I'm a soljer! --

Speaker: mp
Dialogue: That guy ain't no soljer -- he dint HALT --

Speaker: another angle
Dialogue: CAMERA SHOOTS DOWN to Prew from top of trap. A portion of the jeep is in shot, but we are not able to see the MPs.

Speaker: mp's voice
Dialogue: -- maybe he was a soljer -- I dint mean to kill him -- I dint mean it, guys -- you know we got orders --

Speaker: prew's voice
Dialogue: ... sweat it out and sweat it out and wait and wait and wait for it... and now it's here... it's here... gotta see to do it well... gotta do it well... won't take long...

Speaker: prew's voice
Dialogue: ... just a little more now... gotta do it good... it'll be over... nobody lies... lonely... a man has... got to have some place...

Speaker: black leader
Dialogue: There is no sound as the screen remains black for several beats.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: Where's your Company Commander?

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: He's at Headquarters, sir. I'm the First Sergeant.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: Did you know this man personally?

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: He didn't have any regular identification. But they found a card on him with his name --  -- seems to be a membership in a club. The -- New Congress Club.

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: I'll turn this over to you. And these other things that were on him. This --

Speaker: warden's voice
Dialogue: Yes, air.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: And this. Whatever it is.

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: It's the mouthpiece of a bugle.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: Are you all right, Sergeant? Was this man a friend of yours?

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: Sir, this man was a good soldier. He loved the Army moren any soljer I ever knew. I would like to make a formal request that this body be buried in the Army's permanent cemetery at Schofield Barracks.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: I believe I can attend to that for you.

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: lieutenant colonel
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Sergeant.

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: No, sir. I hardly knew the guy...

Speaker: alma's voice
Dialogue: It's very beautiful, isn't it?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I think It's the most beautiful place I ever saw in my lire.

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: No one would know there was a war, from out here.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: There's a legend. If they float in toward shore, you'll come back some day. If they float out to sea, you won't.

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: I won't come back. I had to get away from here. You see, my fiance was killed on December seventh.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Oh, I am sorry.

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: He was a bomber pilot. He tried to taxi his plane off the apron and the Japs made a direct hit on it. Maybe you read about it in the papers. They awarded him a Silver Star. They sent it to his mother. She wrote me she wanted me to have it.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: That's very fine of her.

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: They're very fine people. Southern people. He was named after a General. Robert E. Lee -- Prewitt.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: alma
Dialogue: Robert E. Lee Prewitt.  Isn't that a silly old name?
